question: Will Donald Trump sign between 60 and 90 (inclusive) executive orders in February and March 2025?
reasoning:
Based on the gathered evidence, here is the analysis:

1. **Current Executive Order Count**: As of February 6, 2025, Donald Trump had already signed 58 executive orders. This indicates a high frequency of executive order issuance early in his term.

2. **Historical Context**: The number of executive orders signed by presidents in their first months has been increasing over the years. Trump himself set a record in his previous term with 23 executive orders in Q1 2017.

3. **Trend and Pace**: Given the pace of 58 executive orders by February 6, 2025, it is reasonable to expect that Trump could continue signing executive orders at a high rate through February and March.

4. **Resolution Criteria**: The question resolves as "YES" if Trump signs between 60 and 90 executive orders in February and March 2025. With 58 already signed by early February, reaching the lower bound of 60 seems highly probable.

5. **Official Sources**: The Federal Register and other credible sources like the White House website are tracking these orders, ensuring that the count is accurate and up-to-date.

Considering the above points, the probability that Donald Trump will sign between 60 and 90 executive orders in February and March 2025 is very high.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.95

# Trump's 2025 Executive Orders: Updates and Summaries

President Donald J. Trump was sworn in as the nation's 47th president on Jan. 20, 2025. On his first day back in office, President Trump began implementing many of his campaign promises, signing numerous executive orders targeting key areas such as immigration, trade, energy and federal workforce policies.

Our Public Policy & Regulation team members are actively monitoring and reviewing President Trump's executive orders and other actions. Summaries of newly introduced items can be found below.

Holland & Knight's [Public Policy & Regulation Group](https://www.hklaw.com/en/services/practices/regulatory-and-government-affairs/public-policy-regulation) is a strong bipartisan team composed of lawyers and lobbyists with a comprehensive understanding of the federal legislative and agency policy making processes. We invite you to [learn more](https://issuu.com/hollandknight/docs/holland___knight_-_pp_r_2.16?fr=xKAE9_zU1NQ) about our interdisciplinary approach to solving the issues that are most important to you.

To view a comprehensive tracking chart of executive order summaries, [click here](https://www.hklaw.com/en/general-pages/trumps-2025-executive-orders-chart).

By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered:

Section 1. Purpose. This order continues the reduction in the elements of the Federal bureaucracy that the President has determined are unnecessary.

Sec. 2. Reducing the Scope of the Federal Bureaucracy.

(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the non-statutory components and functions of the following governmental entities shall be eliminated to the maximum extent consistent with applicable law, and such entities shall reduce the performance of their statutory functions and associated personnel to the minimum presence and function required by law:

(i) the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service;

(ii) the United States Agency for Global Media;

(iii) the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in the Smithsonian Institution;

(iv) the Institute of Museum and Library Services;

(v) the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness;

(vi) the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund; and

(vii) the Minority Business Development Agency.

(b) Within 7 days of the date of this order, the head of each governmental entity listed in subsection (a) of this section shall submit a report to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget confirming full compliance with this order and explaining which components or functions of the governmental entity, if any, are statutorily required and to what extent.

(c) In reviewing budget requests submitted by the governmental entities listed in subsection (a) of this section, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget or the head of any executive department or agency charged with reviewing grant requests by such entities shall, to the extent consistent with applicable law and except insofar as necessary to effectuate an expected termination, reject funding requests for such governmental entities to the extent they are inconsistent with this order.

results.title: Immediate Expansion of American Timber Production – The White House
results.snippet: By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Purpose. The production of timber, lumber, paper, bioenergy, and other wood products (timber production) is critical to our Nation’s well-being.

results.title: Modernizing Payments To and From America's Bank Account – The White House
results.snippet: The continued use of paper-based payments by the Federal Government imposes unnecessary costs, delays, and risks of fraud, lost payments, theft, and inefficiencies.

# Trump's 2025 Executive Orders: Updates and Summaries

President Donald J. Trump was sworn in as the nation's 47th president on Jan. 20, 2025. On his first day back in office, President Trump began implementing many of his campaign promises, signing numerous executive orders targeting key areas such as immigration, trade, energy and federal workforce policies.

Our Public Policy & Regulation team members are actively monitoring and reviewing President Trump's executive orders and other actions. Summaries of newly introduced items can be found below.

Holland & Knight's [Public Policy & Regulation Group](https://www.hklaw.com/en/services/practices/regulatory-and-government-affairs/public-policy-regulation) is a strong bipartisan team composed of lawyers and lobbyists with a comprehensive understanding of the federal legislative and agency policy making processes. We invite you to [learn more](https://issuu.com/hollandknight/docs/holland___knight_-_pp_r_2.16?fr=xKAE9_zU1NQ) about our interdisciplinary approach to solving the issues that are most important to you.

To view a comprehensive tracking chart of executive order summaries, [click here](https://www.hklaw.com/en/general-pages/trumps-2025-executive-orders-chart).

content.snippet:
---
title: Continuing the Reduction of the Federal Bureaucracy
url: https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/continuing-the-reduction-of-the-federal-bureaucracy/
hostname: whitehouse.gov
description: By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Purpose.
sitename: The White House
date: 2025-03-15
categories: ['Presidential Actions']
---
By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered:

Section 1. Purpose. This order continues the reduction in the elements of the Federal bureaucracy that the President has determined are unnecessary.

Sec. 2. Reducing the Scope of the Federal Bureaucracy.

(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the non-statutory components and functions of the following governmental entities shall be eliminated to the maximum extent consistent with applicable law, and such entities shall reduce the performance of their statutory functions and associated personnel to the minimum presence and function required by law:

(i) the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service;

(ii) the United States Agency for Global Media;

(iii) the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in the Smithsonian Institution;

(iv) the Institute of Museum and Library Services;

(v) the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness;

(vi) the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund; and

(vii) the Minority Business Development Agency.

(b) Within 7 days of the date of this order, the head of each governmental entity listed in subsection (a) of this section shall submit a report to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget confirming full compliance with this order and explaining which components or functions of the governmental entity, if any, are statutorily required and to what extent.

(c) In reviewing budget requests submitted by the governmental entities listed in subsection (a) of this section, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget or the head of any executive department or agency charged with reviewing grant requests by such entities shall, to the extent consistent with applicable law and except insofar as necessary to effectuate an expected termination, reject funding requests for such governmental entities to the extent they are inconsistent with this order.

Sec. 3. General Provisions. (a) Nothing in this o…

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will Donald Trump sign between 60 and 90 (inclusive) executive orders in February and March 2025?
Background: According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_order):

> In the United States, an executive order is a directive by the president of the United States that manages operations of the federal government. The legal or constitutional basis for executive orders has multiple sources. Article Two of the United States Constitution gives presidents broad executive and enforcement authority to use their discretion to determine how to enforce the law or to otherwise manage the resources and staff of the executive branch. The ability to make such orders is also based on expressed or implied Acts of Congress that delegate to the president some degree of discretionary power (delegated legislation).

The number of Executive Orders that presidents issue in their first months in office has been rising significantly over the past years:

| President      | Period  | Number of EOs |
| -------------- | ------- | ------------- |
| Bill Clinton   | Q1 1993 | 9             |
| George W. Bush | Q1 2021 | 8             |
| Barack Obama   | Q1 2009 | 18            |
| Donald Trump   | Q1 2017 | 23            |
| Joe Biden      | Q1 2021 | 37            |

Trump surpassed all previous records in the first 8 days in office, [having signed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_executive_orders_in_the_second_presidency_of_Donald_Trump) 58 executive orders as of February 6, 2025.
Resolution criteria: This question will resolve as YES if Donald Trump signs between 60 and 90 (inclusive) executive orders in February and March 2025, according to [the Federal Register](https://www.federalregister.gov/presidential-documents/executive-orders).

##### Note that this question closes early, on March 10, 2025.
Fine print: * An Executive Order is any presidential document with an Executive Order number. Orders that do not have such a number will not count for this question.
* If the Federal Register delays in publishing an Executive Order, Metaculus might use alternative credible sources to resolve this question, such as [the Presidential Actions archive](https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/).
* This question will resolve according to the number of Executive Orders signed by Donald Trump in February and March, 2025. The date of publication is immaterial for this question.

# Trump's 2025 Executive Orders: Updates and Summaries

President Donald J. Trump was sworn in as the nation's 47th president on Jan. 20, 2025. On his first day back in office, President Trump began implementing many of his campaign promises, signing numerous executive orders targeting key areas such as immigration, trade, energy and federal workforce policies.

Our Public Policy & Regulation team members are actively monitoring and reviewing President Trump's executive orders and other actions. Summaries of newly introduced items can be found below.

Holland & Knight's [Public Policy & Regulation Group](https://www.hklaw.com/en/services/practices/regulatory-and-government-affairs/public-policy-regulation) is a strong bipartisan team composed of lawyers and lobbyists with a comprehensive understanding of the federal legislative and agency policy making processes. We invite you to [learn more](https://issuu.com/hollandknight/docs/holland___knight_-_pp_r_2.16?fr=xKAE9_zU1NQ) about our interdisciplinary approach to solving the issues that are most important to you.

messages.content:
{"url": "https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/continuing-the-reduction-of-the-federal-bureaucracy/", "snippet": "---
title: Continuing the Reduction of the Federal Bureaucracy
url: https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/continuing-the-reduction-of-the-federal-bureaucracy/
hostname: whitehouse.gov
description: By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Purpose.
sitename: The White House
date: 2025-03-15
categories: ['Presidential Actions']
---
By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered:

Section 1. Purpose. This order continues the reduction in the elements of the Federal bureaucracy that the President has determined are unnecessary.

Sec. 2. Reducing the Scope of the Federal Bureaucracy.

(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the non-statutory components and functions of the following governmental entities shall be eliminated to the maximum extent consistent with applicable law, and such entities shall reduce the performance of their statutory functions and associated personnel to the minimum presence and function required by law:

(i) the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service;

(ii) the United States Agency for Global Media;

(iii) the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in the Smithsonian Institution;

(iv) the Institute of Museum and Library Services;

(v) the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness;

(vi) the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund; and

(vii) the Minority Business Development Agency.

(b) Within 7 days of the date of this order, the head of each governmental entity listed in subsection (a) of this section shall submit a report to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget confirming full compliance with this order and explaining which components or functions of the governmental entity, if any, are statutorily required and to what extent.

(c) In reviewing budget requests submitted by the governmental entities listed in subsection (a) of this section, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget or the head of any executive department or agency charged with reviewing grant requests by such entities shall, to the extent consistent with applicable law and except insofar as necessary to effectuate an expected termination, reject funding requests for such governmental entities to the extent they are inconsistent with this order.

Sec. 3. General Provisions. (a) Nothing in this o…

messages.content:
Based on the gathered evidence, here is the analysis:

1. **Current Executive Order Count**: As of February 6, 2025, Donald Trump had already signed 58 executive orders. This indicates a high frequency of executive order issuance early in his term.

2. **Historical Context**: The number of executive orders signed by presidents in their first months has been increasing over the years. Trump himself set a record in his previous term with 23 executive orders in Q1 2017.

3. **Trend and Pace**: Given the pace of 58 executive orders by February 6, 2025, it is reasonable to expect that Trump could continue signing executive orders at a high rate through February and March.

4. **Resolution Criteria**: The question resolves as "YES" if Trump signs between 60 and 90 executive orders in February and March 2025. With 58 already signed by early February, reaching the lower bound of 60 seems highly probable.

5. **Official Sources**: The Federal Register and other credible sources like the White House website are tracking these orders, ensuring that the count is accurate and up-to-date.

Considering the above points, the probability that Donald Trump will sign between 60 and 90 executive orders in February and March 2025 is very high.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.95
